item.title: Bisq - The P2P Exchange Network
item.dc:creator: @plasticpalmarvin
item.description:
Hi, I‚Äôm trying to set up Bisq in a Qubes/Whonix environment.

I followed the guide in the Whonix wiki/Bisq; the Bisq client runs and outbound connections work fine.

However, I never get inbound connections to the hidden service set up by Bisq, so these must get blocked somehow.
In the Bisq log, there is an entry saying

Nov-10 20:28:43.328 [TorControlParser] DEBUG o.b.n.tor.Tor: hiddenService: HS_DESC RECEIVED [onion addr] NO_AUTH redacted redacted

so apparently, the hidden service is published, but can‚Äôt be reached. I tried to connect with Tor browser, which gives the error message ‚Äúunable to connect‚Äù.
I did run onion-grater-add 40_bisq on sys-whonix
and added
EXTERNAL_OPEN_ALL=true to /usr/local/etc/whonix_firewall.d/50_user.conf
on the workstation qube (a standalone based on whonix-ws-16).

On sys-whonix:

user@host:~$ sudo whonix_firewall -i
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - OK: Loading Whonix firewall‚Ä¶
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - OK: Skipping firewall mode detection since already set to ‚Äòfull‚Äô.
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - OK: (Full torified network access allowed.)
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - INFO: WORKSTATION_TRANSPARENT_TCP=1
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - INFO: WORKSTATION_TRANSPARENT_DNS=1
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - INFO: WORKSTATION_ALLOW_SOCKSIFIED=1
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - INFO: CONTROL_PORT_FILTER_PROXY_ENABLE=1
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - INFO: GATEWAY_ALLOW_INCOMING_DIR_PORT=0
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - INFO: GATEWAY_ALLOW_INCOMING_OR_PORT=0
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - INFO: DIR_PORT=80
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - INFO: OR_PORT=443
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - INFO: GATEWAY_TRANSPARENT_TCP=0
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - INFO: GATEWAY_TRANSPARENT_UDP=0
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - INFO: GATEWAY_TRANSPARENT_DNS=0
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - INFO: ALLOW_GATEWAY_ROOT_USER=0
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - INFO: ALLOW_GATEWAY_USER_USER=0
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - INFO: GATEWAY_ALLOW_INCOMING_SSH=0
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - INFO: GATEWAY_ALLOW_INCOMING_ICMP=0
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - INFO: Opening External TCP port(s): NONE
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - INFO: Opening External UDP port(s): NONE
2022-11-10 20:53:36 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - INFO: WORKSTATION_ALLOW_SOCKSIFIED=‚Äò1‚Äô, Socks Ports will be reacheable from the Workstation
2022-11-10 20:53:37 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - INFO: opening Internal TCP port(s): 9050 9100 9101 9102 9103 9104 9105 9106 9107 9108 9109 9110 9111 9114 9115 9117 9118 9122 9123 9124 9125 9150
2022-11-10 20:53:37 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - INFO: opening TCP port(s) 9152:9189 for user custom applications
2022-11-10 20:53:37 - /usr/bin/whonix-gateway-firewall - OK: Whonix firewall loaded.

And on the Whonix workstation qube:

user@host:~$ sudo whonix_firewall -i
2022-11-10 20:58:20 - /usr/bin/whonix-workstation-firewall - OK: Loading Whonix firewall‚Ä¶
2022-11-10 20:58:20 - /usr/bin/whonix-workstation-firewall - OK: Skipping firewall mode detection since already set to ‚Äòfull‚Äô.
2022-11-10 20:58:20 - /usr/bin/whonix-workstation-firewall - OK: (Full torified network access allowed.)
2022-11-10 20:58:20 - /usr/bin/whonix-workstation-firewall - INFO: Opening External TCP port(s): NONE
2022-11-10 20:58:20 - /usr/bin/whonix-workstation-firewall - INFO: Opening External UDP port(s): NONE
2022-11-10 20:58:20 - /usr/bin/whonix-workstation-firewall - INFO: EXTERNAL_OPEN_ALL=‚Äòtrue‚Äô, all external ports will be opened
2022-11-10 20:58:20 - /usr/bin/whonix-workstation-firewall - OK: Qubes DNS firewall rules ok.
2022-11-10 20:58:21 - /usr/bin/whonix-workstation-firewall - OK: Whonix firewall loaded.

Any ideas what might be causing this? How could I troubleshoot the issue? I‚Äôm quite familiar with Linux and networking, but fairly new to Tor onion services and Qubes/Whonix.

By the way, if I set up an ordinary Debian 11 Qube (with sys-firewall as net qube) following the Bisq Wiki Running_Bisq_on_Qubes guide, everything works just fine ‚Äì but I‚Äôd rather use a Whonix ‚Ä¶

item.title: How to disable DHCP in Whonix and ensure no leaks
item.dc:creator: @NotFound
item.description:
HulaHoop:

I made sure that Whonix KVM does not run or need DHCP in any way shape or form to function. That is why you need to also import an extra external network settings file since all IPs are static and hardcoded.

Thanks for clearing that out! But why does dnsmasq run with this libvirtd ‚ÄúDHCP lease script‚Äù (that is actually a binary) ? While we are at it would be nice to clear out why is dnsmasq is needed as well (separate questions)

item.title: CI Whonix Testing
item.dc:creator: @bee
item.description:
Okay so WATS is almost running, a few changes left. I had to create a huge VPS in order for all the VMs to run with GUI (8gb of RAM).

So once I get WATS running, I will create new functionality to automatically provision servers.

Here is the design plan for 2 scenarios

Developer pushes a commit

  1. trigger CI job to build commit VMs with --remote-derivative-packages
  2. check for existing VMs in account
  3. if VMs do not exist, create 2 very small headless VMs (1gb ram or 2 at most) from template with virtualbox and ssh keys installed
  4. On each VM, build headless workstation and gateway. Do not run WATS
  5. Destroy VPS servers

Doing this in a parrallel manner will speed things up, and hopefully get CI jobs for commits to under 30 minutes.

Developer pushes a tag

  1. check for existing largefootprint VM. If does not exist, create it. 8gb of RAM, XFCE GUI, Virtualbox, etc.
  2. Build both Workstation and Gateway VMs with GUI, and NO remote packages
  3. Run WATS on VMs.
  4. Destroy VPS

This will be a much slower process, probably almost 2 hours to fully test a VM tag with GUI. But this is shorter than manually testing it, and can happen in the background

item.title: Whonix update removed application launcher? Why do this?
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
It‚Äôs not a feature. Whonix source code changes do not include changes which could effect such a change. Could be a bug in a package from Debian.

fuckitalllls:

Is there any way to get this back?

Maybe.

Platform-specific Desktop Tips chapter Default Home Folder Configuration Files Reset in Whonix wiki

Whonix ‚Äì 25 Jul 22

Information Booster might be Available!

Utilizing other resources to help solve questions/issues unspecific to Whonix ‚Ñ¢.

item.title: Whonix update removed application launcher? Why do this?
item.dc:creator: @fuckitalllls
item.description: The icon in the upper left corner that drops down to show applications is now gone with most recent whonix update. I have seen this on two different workstation vm‚Äôs so it is not a error with an update. The only way i can even go to applications now is right click desktop and carefully open the submenus. If it werent for that feature i would be locked out of every program. Is there any way to get this back?

item.title: scurl - secure curl wrapper
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
curl --invalid x

curl: option --invalid: is unknown
curl: try ‚Äòcurl --help‚Äô or ‚Äòcurl --manual‚Äô for more information
zsh: exit 2 curl --invalid x

curl-download --invalid x https://www.kicksecure.com/w/images/2/25/Gui-preview.jpg https://www.kicksecure.com

curl --location --invalid --remote-name x --remote-name https://www.kicksecure.com/w/images/2/25/Gui-preview.jpg --remote-name https://www.kicksecure.com

  • ‚Äú‚Äìinvalid x‚Äù isn‚Äôt correctly passed.
  • It adds an ‚Äú‚Äìremote-name x‚Äù where there was none before.
  • Therefore it produces a different error message compared to non-wrapped curl.

item.title: scurl - secure curl wrapper
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
if echo "${list}" | tr " " "\n" | grep -q "^${res}$"; then

Or better

if echo "${list}" | tr " " "\n" | grep -q "^${res}\$"; then

?

item.title: scurl - secure curl wrapper
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Some shellcheck warnings.

In usr/bin/curl-download line 17:
opt="$opt ‚Äú$res‚Äù"
^-^ SC2089: Quotes/backslashes will be treated literally. Use an array.

In usr/bin/curl-download line 39:
echo curl --location $opt
^‚Äì^ SC2090: Quotes/backslashes in this variable will not be respected.
^‚Äì^ SC2086: Double quote to prevent globbing and word splitting.

Did you mean:
echo curl --location ‚Äú$opt‚Äù

For more information:
https://www.shellcheck.net/wiki/SC2089 ‚Äì Quotes/backslashes will be treate‚Ä¶
https://www.shellcheck.net/wiki/SC2090 ‚Äì Quotes/backslashes in this variab‚Ä¶
ShellCheck: SC2086 ‚Äì Double quote to prevent globbing and word splitting. ‚Äì Double quote to prevent globbing ‚Ä¶
zsh: exit 1 shellcheck usr/bin/curl-download

item.title: Whonix Linux Installer
item.dc:creator: @nyxnor
item.description:
I read the wiki page and I have some portable functions that can be used by the whonix installer:

  • option parsing

  • long opts

  • short opts

  • opt=arg

  • range possible arguments for each option

  • detect os

  • check if program is installed

  • handle installing packages

  • other utilities that are better read than explained

  • colors definition

Just try it and see what fits.

github.com

nyxnor/onionjuggler/blob/main/usr/share/onionjuggler/defaults.sh

#!/usr/bin/env sh
# shellcheck disable=SC2034

## Define default values and functions


###################
#### VARIABLES ####

## don't change here, automatically set by configure.sh
version="0.0.1"

## colors
nocolor="\033[0m"
bold="\033[1m"
#nobold="\033[22m"
underline="\033[4m"
nounderline="\033[24m"
red="\033[31m"
green="\033[32m"
This file has been truncated. show original
github.com

nyxnor/onionjuggler/blob/main/configure.sh

#!/usr/bin/env sh

## This file should be run from inside the cloned repository
## Setup tor directories, user, packages needed for OnionJuggler.

command -v git >/dev/null || { printf '%s\n' "Missing dependency, please install git"; exit 1; }
git_top_dir="$(git rev-parse --show-toplevel || exit 1)"
me="${0##*/}"
version="$(cat "${git_top_dir}"/version.txt)"

usage(){
  printf %s"Configure the environment for OnionJuggler
Usage: ${me} [--option <ARG>]
Options:
  -b, --build                                 build onionjuggler
  -i, --instal                                copy build to path
  -d, --uninstall [-P, --purge]               remove onionjuggler scripts and manual pages from path
  -V, --version
  -h, --help                                  show this help message
\nDev options:
This file has been truncated. show original

Breaks when there are spaces?

item.title: discourse mailing list mode - non-JavaScript way to interact with the discourse forums
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
I found discourse incoming e-mail support to be unreliable.

Discourse Meta ‚Äì 30 Apr 21

Wrong Error Message for too short replies for Reply-by-Email

When sending a too short reply such as ‚Äútesting reply by e-mail‚Äù, I am getting an e-mail back: We‚Äôre sorry, but your email message to [‚Äúdiscoursereplies+redacted.org‚Äù] (titled Re: forum thread title didn‚Äôt work. Do you use more than one email...

Reading time: 2 mins üïë Likes: 16 ‚ù§

Even the infrastructure needed to debug it is missing.

Discourse Meta ‚Äì 9 Jun 21

Reply with debug info to rejected e-mails

In case of issues such as We‚Äôre sorry, but your email message to ["discoursereplies+redacted@redacted.orgredacted] (titled Re:redacted) didn‚Äôt work. Here are some things to check: Do you use more than one email address? Did you reply from a...

Reading time: 1 mins üïë Likes: 1 ‚ù§

Hence if I reply by e-mail I yet have to check later if it actually arrived in the forums. Therefore I am using it rarely.

That‚Äôs why nothing changed since my previous post.

Patrick:

Need to figure out how to use this.

I didn‚Äôt and nobody else did that either. Most likely won‚Äôt happen unless contributed.

Patrick:

I‚Äôve enabled e-mail based creation of new subject in support forums for testing.

Still true. Feel free to research and test this.

item.title: discourse reply by e-mail broken
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
grass:

Also,
can you check if you server is retrying to send rate limited messages?

How to do that?

grass:

I don‚Äôt know why stripping PGP signatures is a good idea.

Discourse Meta ‚Äì 8 Nov 19

Why does Discourse block cryptographic signatures by default?

Discourse‚Äôs default attachment blacklist includes ‚Äòsignature.asc‚Äô files. Why? https://github.com/discourse/discourse/blob/e92f5e4fbf04a88d37dc5069917090abf6c07dec/config/site_settings.yml#L638 It appears that, when attachment blacklists were added...

Reading time: 1 mins üïë Likes: 6 ‚ù§

Asking ‚Äúwhy‚Äù might imply ‚Äúplease fix that‚Äù but isn‚Äôt necessarily understood that way.

Git allows to sign git commit and then git web services such as github show the signature status on the web interface. That‚Äôs quiet neat. Perhaps it would be worth requesting a similar feature from upstream discourse.

item.title: discourse reply by e-mail broken
item.dc:creator: @grass
item.description:
Your e-mail:

Test signed message by mail.

result:

 RateLimiter::LimitExceeded

What is RateLimiter::LimitExceeded for incoming email? - support - Discourse Meta

grass:

Is it possibly to reply by mail with pgp signed message?

E-mail‚Ä¶

grass presentation - #7 by grass

‚Ä¶ was received by discourse with PGP signature intact but it seems discourse is stripping the signatures before presenting the message in the forums and/or ignoring it. In other words, I doubt that discourse upstream has any sort of PGP signatures support. You could try to search meta.discourse.org and/or post a feature request upstream.

Discourse Meta ‚Äì 6 Apr 16

What is RateLimiter::LimitExceeded for incoming email?

The issue is that we poll emails every 5 minutes or so and then create posts in batch, thus hitting the rate limits. The solution is unfortunately not easy

‚ÄúThe issue is that we poll emails every 5 minutes or so and then create
posts in batch, thus hitting the rate limits. The solution is
unfortunately not easy‚Äù

Discourse Meta ‚Äì 8 Aug 16

Replying too quickly ... By email?

Ok, let‚Äôs try this üå∞ https://github.com/discourse/discourse/commit/51322a46b3fabab11cfa8f29ac4f386d8227aedf

github.com/discourse/discourse

FEATURE: retry processing incoming emails on rate limit

committed 08:28PM - 08 Aug 16 UTC
ZogStriP
+61 -15

The problem I that I don‚Äôt receive a reply mail stating that the message
was rate limited, messages can fall in the limbo because of that. Also,
can you check if you server is retrying to send rate limited messages?

Also, even if you enabled discourse attachments, it will be stripped

Discourse Meta ‚Äì 27 Jul 16

Strip PGP signatures

I have a small request, very similar to this one: Could Discourse also strip PGP signatures, named signature.asc?

Reading time: 1 mins üïë Likes: 14 ‚ù§

I don‚Äôt know why stripping PGP signatures is a good idea.

item.title: Whonix source code in self-hosted git
item.dc:creator: @bee
item.description:
anyways I am going to do some more brainstorrming about how we can avoid too many tech giant tools despite it being a bad idea, as a pet project, because I like lighting time on fire and I think it might be useful to other communities as well.

I am going to make good on my word and get WATS running first though. Perhaps tomorrow night

item.title: Whonix source code in self-hosted git
item.dc:creator: @bee
item.description:
I have an idea

If we all quit sleeping, we would have an extra 8 hours a day 365 days a year. Every developer would have an extra 3000 hours a year to implement the most secure and most ethical solutions. Tech giants would imminently crumble, and future civilizations would study the statues society erected to honor our existence.

item.title: How much effort is worth spending on a "perfect webserver for whonix.org"?
item.dc:creator: @bee
item.description:
Patrick:

if all goes well, it‚Äôs invisible effort.

I disagree in some regards, at least when open source tools are used. It swings the pendulum

Perhaps an ‚Äúalmost invisible‚Äù effort, but using a tool like gitea would give more power to the project gitea

Again, not saying we should self host at this juncture in time, but I feel the need to give my opinion anyway

Patrick:

if it gets hacked, it‚Äôs probably resulting in FUD

If you fuck up at your job and get your company hacked, you get a new job and say it ‚Äúwasn‚Äôt a good culture fit‚Äù

If you fuck up and get your open source project hacked, the whole world gets to see exactly who did it LOL

item.title: Whonix source code in self-hosted git
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
grass:

there is no organization of threads except the type: Development

Saw Bug Reports, Software Development and Feature Requests chapter Forum Tags in Whonix wiki? Forum tags‚Ä¶ But maybe also not very usable, unsuitable, messy.

On the other hand, when there was phabricator, there‚Äôs always been lower activity there and then duplication in forums vs phabricator. So the ideal issue tracking which would imo be a forum with easily usable tags/components would be best but that doesn‚Äôt seem to exist.

grass:

I think that if the forum implements a good tracking of
issues, merge requests per repository, then maybe git server with
‚Äúissues‚Äù functionality is not necessary?

I don‚Äôt know any forum that can really provide a unified experience for all of that.

grass:

Could try that, but can‚Äôt attach a patch to the forum right?

In theory could just dump the patch‚Äôs plaintext into code tags. That however might fail in case there‚Äôs any binary data (lets say an icon, image, etc.).

grass:

one thread is one topic, meaning that every new patch is a new topic

Yeah. That what was I had in mind. Just the patch. No discussion. Discussion happening in other forum threads. But that might spam lots of forum threads.

grass:

With a big
enough patch, dumping everything makes it hard to review?

A git patch can express multiple commits.

But, yeah‚Ä¶ Only if a separate forum thread per patch. And then in the main discussion just link to it.

The more I think about it, the posting patches directly to the forums should probably stay the exceptional cases. If used a lot, might quickly trash the forums. And if patches are posted elsewhere (such as on paste websites) and only links to patches posted in forums that might be marginally better. But then paste websites expire. Then web archiving these would be required. Getting more and more messy.

grass:

no dependency on third-parties servers rules and logging

At time of writing, Whonix server - just as any other server for any other project - is also ‚Äúhosted in the cloud‚Äù at a root server (or VPS server) provider. The server provider could also do logging without my consent and/or knowledge. Related:
Placing Trust in Whonix ‚Ñ¢ chapter Self-Hosting vs Third Party Hosting in Whonix wiki
So all of the perfection, a lot of the advantages of no logs for example by self-hosting discourse and not using the hosted version by discourse cloud might actually go out of the window due to the server provider at least in principle having the power to log.

That‚Äôs might be why why Qubes concluded it‚Äôs not worth to even try to optimize for self-hosting:

  • Frequently asked questions (FAQ) | Qubes OS
  • Frequently asked questions (FAQ) | Qubes OS
bee:

This is not reality. Where is it going to be hosted? My house? No the internet is not good enough here

A cloud provider? Thats a third party.

Indeed. Hence written about that here:
Placing Trust in Whonix ‚Ñ¢ chapter Self-Hosting vs Third Party Hosting in Whonix wiki

bee:
  • potential reputational loss if a hack occurs. I am not a terrible sysadmin by any means, but I am a human and much more specialized on infra automation as my day job. Security is something I have learned a good bit, but could still spend a lifetime and not know it all. I could make a mistake, a hack would be embarrassing to the project.
How much effort is worth spending on a "perfect webserver for whonix.org"? Organization
Another great point I wish I had in mind when writing above bullet points. Self-hosting doesn‚Äôt have good incentive structures. If all goes well, it‚Äôs invisible effort. If it gets hacked, it‚Äôs probably resulting in FUD (related: Placing Trust in Whonix ‚Ñ¢ chapter Server Security in Whonix wiki) and ridicule. If using third-party hosting such as github and github gets hacked, then it‚Äôs just a third party that got hacked and the reputation of the project that was using github remains stainless. ‚Ä¶

item.title: How much effort is worth spending on a "perfect webserver for whonix.org"?
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Whonix source code in self-hosted git
  • potential reputational loss if a hack occurs. I am not a terrible sysadmin by any means, but I am a human and much more specialized on infra automation as my day job. Security is something I have learned a good bit, but could still spend a lifetime and not know it all. I could make a mistake, a hack would be embarrassing to the project.

Another great point I wish I had in mind when writing above bullet points. Self-hosting doesn‚Äôt have good incentive structures.

  • If all goes well, it‚Äôs invisible effort.
  • If it gets hacked, it‚Äôs probably resulting in FUD (related: Placing Trust in Whonix ‚Ñ¢ chapter Server Security in Whonix wiki) and ridicule.
  • If using third-party hosting such as github and github gets hacked, then it‚Äôs just a third party that got hacked and the reputation of the project that was using github remains stainless.

Even security experts don‚Äôt claim that they can absolutely secure a webserver / webapps form ever getting hacked. Usually the more of a security expert they are, the more modest they are, the more careful they are to avoid making bold claims of something being secure.

bee:
grass:

Sad to see TPO doing that,

You could donate $100,000 every year for them to have a full time experienced SysAdmin in charge of the task lol

If that would even be enough money to avoid full database losses every other year.

item.title: discourse reply by e-mail broken
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Your e-mail:

Test signed message by mail.

result:

RateLimiter::LimitExceeded
Discourse Meta ‚Äì 17 Feb 16

What is RateLimiter::LimitExceeded for incoming email?

Today I got an item in my ‚ÄúRejected‚Äù emails log with the error: RateLimiter::LimitExceeded However, there‚Äôs no description about why this occurred. Can anyone shed some light? It‚Äôs the only such instance of the error in our logs.

Reading time: 1 mins üïë Likes: 10 ‚ù§

grass:

Is it possibly to reply by mail with pgp signed message?

E-mail‚Ä¶

grass presentation Development
Good news. As long as the email used to create account is accessible it should be possible to contact GitHub support and get flag removed. That is true, I 'd just like to avoid having to hop mail server every time some third-party is unhappy with privacy. Thanks for the reply.

‚Ä¶ was received by discourse with PGP signature intact but it seems discourse is stripping the signatures before presenting the message in the forums and/or ignoring it. In other words, I doubt that discourse upstream has any sort of PGP signatures support. You could try to search meta.discourse.org and/or post a feature request upstream.

item.title: How much effort is worth spending on a "perfect webserver for whonix.org"?
item.dc:creator: @bee
item.description: For what its worth @Patrick, while the phabircator deprecation is certainly annoying, it is not a 100% lost effort. There is an existing script to migrate issues in from phabricator to gitea, if we choose to go that path

item.title: How much effort is worth spending on a "perfect webserver for whonix.org"?
item.dc:creator: @bee
item.description:
grass:

Sad to see TPO doing that,

You could donate $100,000 every year for them to have a full time experienced SysAdmin in charge of the task lol

item.title: How much effort is worth spending on a "perfect webserver for whonix.org"?
item.dc:creator: @bee
item.description:
grass:

I see that discourse must be much more
difficult to self-host than a git server, or so I expect.

No. It is same amount of effort, for me at least.

The discourse instance I hosted for 3 years and cost me about 50-100 hours of time.

Patrick:

Such as:

  • all software on the server must only be using Freedom Software
  • ideally the server would be self-hosted in a developer‚Äôs private home (not hosted at a server provider)
  • JavaScript free webapp or at least basic non-JavaScript support
  • the webapp must not have anti-features such as cookies, tracking
  • no loading of third-party content (such as fonts, CSS, scripts, let alone analytics)
  • no use of a CDN
  • the webapp must have perfect security
  • the webapp must be under constant development and be constantly updated by upstream and downstream

These are wish lists, not requirements. It doesnt have to be all or nothing

Again, i could go either way. I want to make the project better and dont care about my ego. Of course i think creating a webserver ( not whonix owned) on gitfoss.org is a good idea, i bought the domain. But my ego is less important than whonix continuing to succeed for many more years

item.title: Whonix source code in self-hosted git
item.dc:creator: @bee
item.description:
grass:

no dependency on third-parties servers rules and logging

This is not reality. Where is it going to be hosted? My house? No the internet is not good enough here

A cloud provider? Thats a third party.

My opinion

advantages of self hosting gitea

  • Reduce dependency on microsoft. When i ask people why they use facebook/insta/twitter, they generally say ‚Äúall my friends use it‚Äù‚Ä¶ It creates a loop. Someone needs to break the loop!

  • Leverage project boards and issue tracking to help collaborators

  • Create a place for multiple projects beyond whonix/kicksecure to live.

disadvantages of self hosting

  • Time. I would be willing to take this on, but it would take away other work i could do to help whonix. I dont know how much this matters though if it works and helps the project at large become more productive. If I can speed up work for 5 people, but slow myself down this is probably fine

  • Money. Cloud servers arent free (nor are physical servers). I already pay $25 a month for our CI server and automated testing. I could ask Patrick for this money, but rather prefer to treat it as a donation for now. Once WATS is running I will collaborate getting a whonix owned server set up. But for now, this is an out of pocket expense. Regardless who pays it, a collaborator or the project itself, it still costs money.

  • potential reputational loss if a hack occurs. I am not a terrible sysadmin by any means, but I am a human and much more specialized on infra automation as my day job. Security is something I have learned a good bit, but could still spend a lifetime and not know it all. I could make a mistake, a hack would be embarrassing to the project.

item.title: Streamlining Dev Collaboration
item.dc:creator: @bee
item.description:
Yeah this has been a big factor in not setting one up, but I could get it running in a day.

I would use gitea, which has issue tracking and the like. IMO there is little need for hosting one it if it isnt solving the phabricator deprecation issue as well (which gitea satisfies)

When I registered gitfoss.org, my thought was that we could find other projects as well to host there‚Ä¶perhaps graphene, onionshare, richochet, whoever.

Having a standalone server for one codebase seems silly, but having a central place for many privacy FOSS projects, with organized issue tracking, project boards, and other nice features including CI integrations‚Ä¶pie in the sky maybe, but it was my dream when i registered the domain

Also we have like 5 threads for this subject right now‚Ä¶seems like a good argument for centralized issue tracking

item.title: Tor Entry Guards
item.dc:creator: @HulaHoop
item.description: Making the Tor guards page easier to understand is on my long list but eventually I‚Äôll do it. This thread you ink to is unfortunately of littel value since no reputable dev has chimed in, but they need not do so since this question has already been settled by a researcher whose work guides their dev planning.

item.title: post-quantum cryptography - PQC
item.dc:creator: @HulaHoop
item.description:
TNT_BOM_BOM:

anybody audited the code/checked for its security effectiveness

I had someone very smart look at it and give it and give it his approval.

TNT_BOM_BOM:

The idea of using dead project is something, and using it to solve
future attacks which has yet to come something else.

Sometimes mature codebases no longer need updates and work well into the future. Unless you have a paper on its mainly used algo being broken by a new attack, this software is good to go.

item.title: How to disable DHCP in Whonix and ensure no leaks
item.dc:creator: @HulaHoop
item.description: I made sure that Whonix KVM does not run or need DHCP in any way shape or form to function. That is why you need to also import an extra external network settings file since all IPs are static and hardcoded.

item.title: discourse reply by e-mail broken
item.dc:creator: @grass
item.description:
Is it possibly to reply by mail with pgp signed message?
I couldn‚Äôt make it work (mail sent today 08 Nov).

I replied by mail to grass presentation - #5 by h3xagonal with contents ‚ÄúTest signed message by mail.‚Äù, sent to Whonix Forum discoursereplies+5d0c914d70dcc4af8fda7beef221296d@whonix.org, but the mail didn‚Äôt appear on the thread, although for other replies I made by mail to other threads (unsigned), the replied appeared.
Maybe there is a filter?

Can you check on the mail server what happened to the message? I retried already a second time.

item.title: grass presentation
item.dc:creator: @grass
item.description:
Good news. As long as the email used to create account is accessible it should be possible to contact GitHub support and get flag removed.

That is true, I 'd just like to avoid having to hop mail server every
time some third-party is unhappy with privacy. Thanks for the reply.

item.title: How much effort is worth spending on a "perfect webserver for whonix.org"?
item.dc:creator: @grass
item.description:
From my experience with other webapps‚Ä¶

  • wordpress blog (updating was messy, kept breaking),
  • discourse forums (hard to resolve update issues, database issues),
  • mediawiki (update issues, database issues),
  • phabrictor (deprecated even though one would thing that‚Äôs unlikely given it was in use by at least two major users such as wikipedia and facebook)

‚Ä¶that‚Äôs hours and hours of work that are spend on a perfect webserver rather than on software development.

More generally‚Ä¶ Not just about git‚Ä¶ Any webapp or server setup‚Ä¶ The issue is that the demands from a small vocal minority of highly technical users lead a lot of project resources being redirected that aren‚Äôt really beneficial for the core of Whonix which is the actual downloadable software or source code. Such as:

  • all software on the server must only be using Freedom Software
  • ideally the server would be self-hosted in a developer‚Äôs private home (not hosted at a server provider)
  • JavaScript free webapp or at least basic non-JavaScript support
  • the webapp must not have anti-features such as cookies, tracking
  • no loading of third-party content (such as fonts, CSS, scripts, let alone analytics)
  • no use of a CDN
  • the webapp must have perfect security
  • the webapp must be under constant development and be constantly updated by upstream and downstream

These ideal-world requirements are commendable but realistically I wonder these have hold back too much the software development of Whonix. By comparison, the official Tor Project forums forums.torproject.net, by an organisation with much more funding, multiple full time staff, are currently cloud hosted by a third party, discourse which includes IP logging. Source: [tor-talk] torproject forum hosted by 3rd party?

Sad to see TPO doing that, but I see that discourse must be much more
difficult to self-host than a git server, or so I expect.
It is difficult for me to argue again on my point because I don‚Äôt want
to damage development by spending more time during maintenance of hosted
servers than development.
If the burden of maintenance is worth the organization of issues, then
maybe?

related:
Placing Trust in Whonix ‚Ñ¢ chapter Trusting the_Whonix Website in Whonix wiki

Not sure I would be trusting more the infrastructure if still doing
signature verification.

item.title: Whonix source code in self-hosted git
item.dc:creator: @grass
item.description:
Is it really, really required for Whonix to self-host any more webapps?

If it is something heavy to maintain, then no.

There‚Äôs no need to send a pull request to github. Sure, that‚Äôs neat but fully optional. Due to the distributed nature of git, any git branch posted to any git server anywhere worldwide would work. After notification here in the forums, I could locally add the git remote server, git fetch, git diff and consider git merge.

Can be‚Ä¶ I just find this difficult to keep track:

  • there is no organization of threads except the type: Development
  • one thread is one topic, meaning that every new patch is a new topic
  • with every new topic relating to different repositories, it becomes
    hard to keep track, you have to start searching the threads to see where
    a discussion for 1 patch to be done for 1 repository was first started
  • with hosted git server with issues, this is not a problem because
    issues can be tagged and are per repository and not per
  • if using a git server without issues‚Ä¶ then would have to rely solely
    on forums.

If the ‚Äúissues‚Äù issue could be resolved by setting proper tags per
thread and the repository being mentioned on the thread‚Äôs name. e.g.
repoX: patchY, for easier search.

Git even supports creation of single file patch files which could be pasted somewhere here in the forums.

Could try that, but can‚Äôt attach a patch to the forum right? With a big
enough patch, dumping everything makes it hard to review? To make
changes on top of the discussed point?

What‚Äôs the big advantage of a git (or any) server self-hosted by Whonix compared to any git branch in any git repository anywhere or git patch format? And is the extra effort really justified for the maintenance required for that webapp? Maintenance required: initial setup, keeping it updated, backups and restoration testing, archival, troubleshooting if something breaks‚Ä¶

  • no dependency on third-parties servers rules and logging
  • no need to handle different remote servers from different
    contributors, still need to git fetch/pull remote tho.
    About maintenance, if it is too cumbersome, then of course not.

From my experience with other webapps‚Ä¶ See:
How much effort is worth spending on a "perfect webserver for whonix.org"?

If any self-hosted git server, which one? A lightweight one? Which feature are required? Or a more feature-rich one such as gitlab with issues tracking and whatnot?

I am not an expert on the different git servers to make an informed
decision. I think that if the forum implements a good tracking of
issues, merge requests per repository, then maybe git server with
‚Äúissues‚Äù functionality is not necessary?

item.title: discourse mailing list mode - non-JavaScript way to interact with the discourse forums
item.dc:creator: @grass
item.description: Was creating new thread by mail done? If so, how to use it?

item.title: post-quantum cryptography - PQC
item.dc:creator: @TNT_BOM_BOM
item.description:
Not sure if either is really checked thoroughly, if we talk about usage
well how many users or any other projects using it? and really did
checked the source code? and if we talk cryptographically do we have
anybody audited the code/checked for its security effectiveness?

The idea of using dead project is something, and using it to solve
future attacks which has yet to come something else.

Either something actively maintained exist or there is none.

Patrick via Whonix Forum:

item.title: How much effort is worth spending on a "perfect webserver for whonix.org"?
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Whonix source code in self-hosted git - #2 by Patrick

What‚Äôs the big advantage of a git (or any) server self-hosted by Whonix compared to any git branch in any git repository anywhere or git patch format? And is the extra effort really justified for the maintenance required for that webapp? Maintenance required: initial setup, keeping it updated, backups and restoration testing, archival, troubleshooting if something breaks‚Ä¶

From my experience with other webapps‚Ä¶

  • wordpress blog (updating was messy, kept breaking),
  • discourse forums (hard to resolve update issues, database issues),
  • mediawiki (update issues, database issues),
  • phabrictor (deprecated even though one would thing that‚Äôs unlikely given it was in use by at least two major users such as wikipedia and facebook)

‚Ä¶that‚Äôs hours and hours of work that are spend on a perfect webserver rather than on software development.

More generally‚Ä¶ Not just about git‚Ä¶ Any webapp or server setup‚Ä¶ The issue is that the demands from a small vocal minority of highly technical users lead a lot of project resources being redirected that aren‚Äôt really beneficial for the core of Whonix which is the actual downloadable software or source code. Such as:

  • all software on the server must only be using Freedom Software
  • ideally the server would be self-hosted in a developer‚Äôs private home (not hosted at a server provider)
  • JavaScript free webapp or at least basic non-JavaScript support
  • the webapp must not have anti-features such as cookies, tracking
  • no loading of third-party content (such as fonts, CSS, scripts, let alone analytics)
  • no use of a CDN
  • the webapp must have perfect security
  • the webapp must be under constant development and be constantly updated by upstream and downstream

These ideal-world requirements are commendable but realistically I wonder these have hold back too much the software development of Whonix. By comparison, the official Tor Project forums forums.torproject.net, by an organisation with much more funding, multiple full time staff, are currently cloud hosted by a third party, discourse which includes IP logging. Source: [tor-talk] torproject forum hosted by 3rd party?

item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Is it really, really required for Whonix to self-host any more webapps?

There‚Äôs no need to send a pull request to github. Sure, that‚Äôs neat but fully optional. Due to the distributed nature of git, any git branch posted to any git server anywhere worldwide would work. After notification here in the forums, I could locally add the git remote server, git fetch, git diff and consider git merge.

Git even supports creation of single file patch files which could be pasted somewhere here in the forums.

What‚Äôs the big advantage of a git (or any) server self-hosted by Whonix compared to any git branch in any git repository anywhere or git patch format? And is the extra effort really justified for the maintenance required for that webapp? Maintenance required: initial setup, keeping it updated, backups and restoration testing, archival, troubleshooting if something breaks‚Ä¶

From my experience with other webapps‚Ä¶ See:

Streamlining Dev Collaboration - #22 by bee

Gitea compared to other Git hosting options - Docs

item.title: grass presentation
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Whonix source code in self-hosted git Website
Hello, would love to see Whonix self hosting the git server. I have problems with github, they block certain providers and certain IPs. Hi, Thank you for contacting GitHub Support. Our abuse detecting systems flagged this account because of the email address on the account. The email provider is not permitted for use on GitHub accounts. In addition to that, you appear to have registered multiple free user accounts. Our Terms of Service state that an individual may not maintain more than o‚Ä¶

item.title: Streamlining Dev Collaboration
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description: Do you mean setting up a git server?

item.title: grass presentation
item.dc:creator: @h3xagonal
item.description:
grass:

My github account is flagged because of creation over Tor, so public view not yet available.

GitHub might flag accounts it suspects are precursors to malicious usage.

Good news. As long as the email used to create account is accessible it should be possible to contact GitHub support and get flag removed.

Thank you

item.title: Streamlining Dev Collaboration
item.dc:creator: @bee
item.description: Want me to do it @Patrick ? Just waiting for you to be onboard before going forward with it. You are the captain
